introduction.p: To multiply two fractions together, we multiply their numerators together, and multiply their denominators together. We can divide out any common factors in numerator and denominator before we multiply.

assemblage.title: To add or subtract unlike fractions

ol.li: Find the LCD for the fractions.
Build each fraction to an equivalent one with the LCD as its denominator.
Add or subtract the numerators. Keep the same denominator.

solution.p: These are like fractions, so we need only combine their numerators. \dfrac{2x}{w} - \dfrac{3x}{w} = \dfrac{2x-3x}{w} = \dfrac{-x}{w}
These are like fractions, so we need only combine their numerators. Be careful to subtract both terms of the second numerator. \dfrac{3}{a} - \dfrac{a+2}{a} = \dfrac{3-(a+2)}{a} = \dfrac{1-a}{a}
We write 2 as a fraction, \dfrac{2}{1}, and build it to the LCD, x. \dfrac{2}{1} \cdot \alert{\dfrac{x}{x}} + \dfrac{1}{x} = \dfrac{2x}{x} + \dfrac{1}{x} = \dfrac{2x+1}{x}

introduction.p: Be careful when simplifying radicals after extracting roots.

statement.p:
Can you simplify the first expression into the second expression? (Decide whether the expressions are equivalent.)
Is ~~\sqrt{4+x^2}~~ equivalent to ~~2+x?
Is ~~\sqrt{\dfrac{x^2}{9}}~~ equivalent to ~~\dfrac{x}{3}~~ for ~x \ge 0?
Is ~~\sqrt{w-3}~~ equivalent to ~~\sqrt{w} - \sqrt{3}?

li.p: If the expressions are equivalent, they must be equal for every value of the variable. Let's test with x=3. Then \sqrt{4+x^2} \amp = \sqrt{4+9} = \sqrt{13} \approx 3.6 \text{but}~~~~~~~~~ 2+x \amp = 2+3 = 5 No, the expressions are not equivalent.

Because \left(\dfrac{x}{3}\right)^2 = \dfrac{x}{3} \cdot \dfrac{x}{3} = \dfrac{x^2}{3^2} = \dfrac{x^2}{9}, it is also true that \sqrt{\dfrac{x^2}{9}} = \dfrac{x}{3}. Yes, the expressions are equivalent.
Let w=16. Then \sqrt{w-3} \amp = \sqrt{16-3} = \sqrt{13} \approx 3.6 \text{but}~~~ \sqrt{w}-\sqrt{3} \amp = \sqrt{16}-\sqrt{3} \approx 4-1.7 = 2.3 No, the expressions are not equivalent.

subsubsection.title: Exercises
subsubsection.p: Decide whether the expressions are equivalent. Assume all variables are positive.
